title: Standard of Value

articles.content: The Objectivist ethics holds man’s life as the standard of value—and his own life as the ethical purpose of every individual man.
articles.attribution:
“The Objectivist Ethics,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 25

articles.content: The standard of value of the Objectivist ethics—the standard by which one judges what is good or evil—is man’s life, or: that which is required for man’s survival qua man.
articles.attribution:
“The Objectivist Ethics,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 23

articles.content: “Man’s survival qua man” means the terms, methods, conditions and goals required for the survival of a rational being through the whole of his lifespan—in all those aspects of existence which are open to his choice.
articles.attribution:
“The Objectivist Ethics,”
The Virtue of Selfishness, 24
